statement.tex: \text{Differentiate the following}\\ f(x) = (x \cos x)^x + (x \sin x)^{1/x} \\ \text{with respect to x.}

step.context: \text{Which of the following shows the}\\ \text{mathematically correct way to start solving?}
step.tex: \begin{align} f(x) & = (x \cos x)^x + (x \sin x)^{1/x} \\ \implies \log f(x) & = \log (x \cos x)^x + \log (x \sin x)^{1/x} \\ & = x \cdot \log ( x \cos x ) + \dfrac{1}{x}\cdot \log (x \sin x) \\ \end{align}\\ \therefore f'(x) = \frac{d}{dx}[x \cdot \log ( x \cos x ) ] + \frac{d}{dx}\left[ \dfrac{1}{x} \cdot \log (x \sin x) \right]

step.context: \text{If }g(x) = (x \cos x)^x ,\text{ then which of the following}\\ \text{shows the correct evaluation of }g'(x)?
step.tex:
\begin{align} g(x) &= (x \cos x)^x \\ \implies \log g(x) &= x \cdot \log (x \cos x) \\ \end{align}\\
\frac{1}{g(x)} g'(x) = \underbrace{\left[ x \frac{d}{dx}\log(x \cos x) + \log(x \cos x) \frac{d}{dx} x\right ]}_{\textbf{Product Rule}} \\
\, = \left[ \underbrace{x\frac{d \log(x \cos x)}{d \,x \cos x }\cdot \frac {d\, x \cos x}{dx}}_{\textbf{Chain Rule}} + \log (x \cos x ) \frac{d}{dx}x\right] \\
\implies g'(x) = (x \cos x)^{x} \left[ \,1 - x \cdot \tan x + \log (x \cos x)\right]
